title: How to Make a Mastectomy Bra from a Regular Bra

steps.headline: Buy a full-coverage or full-figure bra with cups large enough to completely cover your prosthesis (fake breast).
Try it on to make sure the prosthesis fits in on all sides and that the neckline of the bra fits close against your skin and doesn’t gape.
Choose some fabric.
steps.description: You need about one square foot. An old t-shirt is ideal.

steps.headline: Place the fabric on a table.
steps.description: Then, rest the bra on the table, facing up, with the relevant cup positioned over the fabric. Cut the fabric, leaving about one inch of fabric visible outside of the cup area on all sides.

steps.headline: Sew with the outside of the bra facing up.
steps.description: Begin sewing a straight stitch at the intersection of the cup and shoulder strap near where your armpit would be when worn.

steps.headline: Sew along the top edge of the bra from the strap to the center.
steps.description: To make your stitches less noticeable, sew on top of any existing stitching wherever possible.

steps.headline: Continue the stitch along the top side of the underwire along the underside of the cup until you reach the band, then stop and tie off your thread.
steps.description: Note: Depending on the shape of your bra, you may need to sew some of the open edge so that it is large enough to accommodate inserting and removing the prosthesis without being so large that it could fall out accidentally.

steps.headline: Carefully cut off any excess fabric, leaving a flap at the opening.
steps.description: Then fold the flap over the exposed portion of the prosthesis and tuck it into the bra.

tyn: Foam breast form or fiber fill
text: Buy a full-coverage or full-figure bra with cups large enough to completely cover your prosthesis (fake breast).  Try it on to make sure the prosthesis fits in on all sides and that the neckline of the bra fits close against your skin and doesn’t gape.  Choose some fabric. You need about one square foot. An old t-shirt is ideal. Place the fabric on a table. Then, rest the bra on the table, facing up, with the relevant cup positioned over the fabric. Cut the fabric, leaving about one inch of fabric visible outside of the cup area on all sides. Use a sewing machine.  Sew with the outside of the bra facing up. Begin sewing a straight stitch at the intersection of the cup and shoulder strap near where your armpit would be when worn. Sew along the top edge of the bra from the strap to the center. To make your stitches less noticeable, sew on top of any existing stitching wherever possible. Continue the stitch along the top side of the underwire along the underside of the cup until you reach the band, then stop and tie off your thread. Note: Depending on the shape of your bra, you may need to sew some of the open edge so that it is large enough to accommodate inserting and removing the prosthesis without being so large that it could fall out accidentally. Carefully cut off any excess fabric, leaving a flap at the opening. Then fold the flap over the exposed portion of the prosthesis and tuck it into the bra.
